1. A 28-year-old male software engineer presents with a two-year history of progressive unsteady gait and difficulty with fine motor tasks such as buttoning his shirt. He has noticed frequent falls and slurred speech, which have gradually worsened, impacting his ability to work. On examination, he demonstrates truncal ataxia, dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing, and mild dysarthria. There is no family history of neurological disorders, and routine blood tests are unremarkable. Brain MRI reveals cerebellar atrophy predominantly involving the hemispheres. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the gene associated with Spinocerebellar Ataxia Type 16. He reports no visual symptoms or sensory deficits, and his cognitive function remains intact. Supportive care including physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.
